item.title: A Person Who Loves What He is Doing
item.description: More than two years ago, 2016 November, I started learning R as part of a company push to be more data centric in our decision making. I found programming difficult to learn, but the opportunity R and data science offered encouraged me to continue pursuing it. Soon, I was able to apply R and data science to my work. Last 2018 December 3, I started a new role as a junior data scientist in the research and development department.

item.title: General Cubic Curve: Point of Inflection and Symmetry
item.description: 1 Problem 2 Solution 2.1 Point of Inflection 2.2 Maximum and Minimum 2.3 Average of the Extrema 2.4 Symmetry and the XY-System 3 Plot of the Generic Cubic Curve 4 Reference 1 Problem Problem 40, page 157 in Simmons (2016) Consider the general cubic equation \[ \begin{equation} y = a x^3 + b x^2 + c x + d \tag{1.1} \end{equation} \] Show that: It has one and only one point of inflection at \(I (\frac{-b}{3a}, k)\) where \(k = \frac{2 b^3}{27 a^2} - \frac{bc}{3a} + d\), It has one maximum point and one minimum point if and only if \(b^2 - 3ac \gt 0\), The abscissa of \(I\) is the average of the abscissas of the maximum and minimum point, and The curve is symmetric with respect to \(I\) by Introducing a new \(X\)-axis and \(Y\)-axis such that \(X = x + \frac{b}{3a}\) and \(Y = y - k\) and making \(I\) as the origin of the \(XY\)-system, Showing that the equation of the curve in the \(XY\)-system is \(Y = aX \left(X^2 - \frac{b^2 - 3ac}{3 a^2} \right)\), and Showing that this transformed equation is symmetric with respect to \(I\).
